text:
‚Ä¢H E R O I N E‚Ä¢ 

I don‚Äôt think I could write a review that gives this book and the topics it covers the credit it deserves. 

Mickey is a successful softball player who gets into a car accident and her prescription to help the pain of her injury turns into doing anything possible to get her next fix.  She wants nothing more than to be able to function the same way she did before her accident and instead of turning to painkillers to ‚Äúparty‚Äù or ‚Äúhave fun‚Äù she uses them to get through life and feel normal.  This book was raw, it was real, it was emotional and it was uncomfortable to read at times but it is so realistic.  This hit close to home for me because just like Mickey, I was a successful softball player, college bound, who needed shoulder surgery a few years ago.  And while I never turned to pain meds, the reality is that this could happen to anyone. 

Below are just a few resources available for those struggling with addiction but there are many more: 
Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA): www.samhas.gov 
National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA): www.drugabuse.gov
Narcotics Anonymous (NA): www.na.org 

*This book starts with a trigger warning and recovering addicts should heed this and proceed with caution.  There is details of pills, snorting, needles, bodily functions, car accident, brief hospital stay.*

Heroine by Mindy McGinnis

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Heroine was heartbreaking, breathtaking, powerful and beautifully written. Typically I do not choose YA novels to read, but I am SO glad I picked this one up.

Mindy McGinnis explores the Opioid crisis and how addiction touches all lives. Mickey is a varsity softball player, hoping to be recruited for a local college, until she and her best friend are in a life changing car accident. Mickey‚Äôs hip is destroyed and her goal is to be physically back to normal in order to play softball. In order to get there, Mickey relies heavily on the painkillers her doctors prescribe. Very quickly, Mickey‚Äôs need increases. She is no longer sure if she is relying on the opioids for pain control or for emotional support and acceptance. With friends, family and teachers concerned, Mickey‚Äôs control spirals. 

This book was not easy to read, but touches on a very important subject. Addiction and the Opioid crisis are real. This is an issue that does not discriminate and can touch everyone. 

‚ÄúI am not a wasted person. I am not prowling the streets. I am not an addict. I am a girl spinning her locker combination. I am a girl who got a B on her math test. I am a girl who has two holes on the inside of her arm, but they do not tell the whole story of me.‚Äù

If you are struggling with addiction, please know that help and support are out there. 

https://amzn.to/3n8RInS

üìöBook Review üìö
Heroine by Mindy McGinnis ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è/5 
I‚Äôm going to start this review off with a major trigger warning. If you are extremely sensitive to drug use, drug abuse and/or addiction proceed with caution if considering this book. It is so well written and paints a not so pretty picture of what it would be like to be an addict. Mickey Catalan seems to have it all, a family who loves her, a talent for playing softball, best friends and scholarship options for college. Everything changes when she‚Äôs in a car accident and turns to OxyContin to numb the physical and emotional pain. From there it‚Äôs just a slippery slope. This book was tragically heartbreaking but in the end uplifting. It would be the perfect book for a counselor or social worker to read. I‚Äôm so glad I read this because it was so eye opening!

I could not put this book down! Such a great story from the point of view of the addict and how they got there!
üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü
When a car crash sidelines Mickey just before softball season, she has to find a way to hold on to her spot as the catcher for a team expected to make a historic tournament run. Behind the plate is the only place she‚Äôs ever felt comfortable, and the painkillers she‚Äôs been prescribed can help her get there.

The pills do more than take away pain; they make her feel good.

With a new circle of friends‚Äîfellow injured athletes, others with just time to kill‚ÄîMickey finds peaceful acceptance, and people with whom words come easily, even if it is just the pills loosening her tongue.

But as the pressure to be Mickey Catalan heightens, her need increases, and it becomes less about pain and more about want, something that could send her spiraling out of control.

‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è/5
Page Count: 434

Folly was a wonderful surprise of a book. It was so well-written and I really enjoyed the main character Rae. She was witty, relatable and so resilient of a character it was hard not to fall in love!

Rae Newborn has survived more than her fair share of strife, struggle and pain. She needs a new leaf to turn over and a new place to build upon. Folly is a natural wildlife island preserve and the only piece to her grandfather that wasn‚Äôt completely soured by his presence or over-bearing memories. Rae intends to build a home for herself and shake the spidering memories crawling from deep within both her mind and heart. She‚Äôs convinced herself the noises on the island are the wildlife, but who can ever be sure...

This was a really great read! There were several twists I truly did not even see coming. SPOILER: I really enjoyed how Rae went from being so fearful of her own self to the heroine of the story.

PS. The giveaway winners for my birthday giveaway are @girl.tina23 and @dani.alex2004. I wanted to say a HUGE thank you to the 700 of y‚Äôall that entered. It means the world!

Mickey Catalan is the catcher for her high school softball team. After being in a car accident, she is prescribed opioids. She doesn‚Äôt want to lose her spot on the team, and the pills not only take away the pain, they make her feel good. 

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è The book gives a very raw, unfiltered look into using drugs, and how amazing it makes Mickey feel. It doesn‚Äôt hold back. But it also doesn‚Äôt shy away from the effects and consequences of drug use and addiction. I really liked the flow of this story, and thought Mindy McGinnis did a good job navigating such a sensitive topic. 

The chapters are short and easy to read which is good because the content is heavy. Each chapter begins with a word and it‚Äôs definition, acting as a foreshadow for what the chapter is going to be about.

TW: substance abuse, addiction (oxy, heroin) 

#heroine #heroinebook #mindymcginnisheroine #mindymcginnis #bookreview #coffee #bookstagram #books #katherinetegenbooks #harpercollins

4.5‚≠êÔ∏è out of 5
I've read three books by this author and once again, I am impressed with her writing talent. Addiction is a topic that has been explored in many fiction books, but yet after reading this book, I felt like it was covered it in a way that was unique but also very realistic. A worthwhile read for sure.

High school senior Mickey is determined to have a standout softball season this year. The better she plays, the more likely she will receive scholarship offers for college. But a car accident leaves her badly injured right before the start of the season. Mickey is determined to not miss a game and she needs to quickly get her body in shape. Physical therapy by itself isn't going to get her where she needs to be so she turns to painkillers. 
Despite the fact the story is about a teenager with an addiction, for the most part I didn't feel like this was a heavy read and I actually think that is one of the strengths of the novel. Don't get me wrong, there are some emotional moments in the book, but I never felt overwhelmed by the story. It was straightforward and was a realistic portrayal of how easy it is to slip into addiction. When comparing it to other books I have read on the topic, this one managed to get all the main points across but in a way that was easier to mentally process. That's my opinion though as maybe other readers will find it to be a difficult read.

What was fascinating to me was Mickey became addicted to painkillers because she had goals and she wasn't going to let anything stand in her way. She wanted the ability to function like she did before the accident and painkillers were supposed to aid her in getting back to normal. The author took a unique approach as most stories would have focused on a teenager using painkillers only as a coping mechanism rather than trying to achieve something.

Full review posted on Goodreads. (profile link in bio)

Category: Young Adult Fiction‚†Ä
Title: Heroine by Mindy McGinnis‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Nominated by: Wendy Gassaway, who blogs at Falconer's Library

Mickey Catalan has a life filled with scars, but that doesn't hold her back from kicking butt and taking names behind the plate. That is, until the accident.

Three screws in her hip that grind away at her chances--a chance for a historic tournament run, a chance for scholarships, a chance for a bright future.

Two months until spring training; the screws stand in the way of her dreams. It would take a miracle to get back into the shape she once was. A miracle in the form of pharmaceuticals.

The pills do more than take the edge off the grinding pain; they make her feel good. Pain and pleasure are a slippery slope, and Mickey is sliding off home plate--into an abyss known as #Heroine.

5/5 üåü
Heroine fue esa clase de libros que te llama desde lejos, y vos sabes internamente que lo tenes que leer porque esconde una gran historia dentro de √©l. 
Este libro es un diamante en bruto, es sublime, tiene una estructura incre√≠ble. Hacia muchisimo tiempo que no le√≠a una historia que me pusiera la piel de gallina, que me haga para de leer por no poder soportar lo que le estaba viviendo nuestra protagonista. Es dif√≠cil ver c√≥mo una chica que tiene todo el futuro pr√°cticamente resuelto, en poco meses se le viene abajo, vemos c√≥mo en tan poco tiempo la droga desmorona su vida, nos muestra c√≥mo las decisiones que tomamos pueden hacer que todo se bifurque y terminemos en cualquier lado menos en donde debemos estar. 
Mickey termina eligiendo una "felicidad" pasajera, antes que un futuro alegre, decide acercarse a personas que est√°n tan rotas como ella, en vez de apoyarse en aquellas que saben de su sufrimiento y pueden ayudarla a levantarse. 
Es incre√≠ble ver como la hero√≠na comienza a ser parte de su vida y sin darte cuenta, empiezas a simpatizar con ella. Como lectora, empec√© a "justificar" los actos de nuestra protagonista como si lo que hac√≠a estaba correcto, solo por el hecho de pensar "pobre, lo necesita, tiene dolor, pas√≥ por mucho".
La pluma de la autora es impecable, transparente y maravillosa a tal punto que te deja secuelas, te deja una gran ense√±anza al final. Yo nunca consum√≠ drogas y jamas me llamaron la atenci√≥n, pero si necesitaba un "alerta"que me reafirmar√° lo mucho que pueden llegar a jodernos la vida, esta fue la forma perfecta. Cada vez que leo afirm√≥ que hay ciertas historias que llegan a nuestras manos en el momento que menos lo esperamos pero que es el m√°s indicado. Este libro, como muchos otros me lo muestran a diario.
No lo recomiendo porque se recomienda solo, pero en serio, si tienen la oportunidad de leerlo h√°ganlo porque les va a abrir mucho los ojos, probablemente m√°s de lo que ya los tienen abiertos.

‚ÄúI admit to myself that I am a heroin user, while also updating in my mind what that actually means. I am not a wasted person, I am not prowling the streets. I am not an addict. I am a girl spinning her locker combination. I am a girl who got a B on her math test. I am a girl who has two holes on the inside of her arm, but they do not tell the whole story of me.‚Äù - I just read my first 5 star novel of the year and the BEST book I have read in a LONG time. Heroine is a story every parent, teenager, grandparent, and teacher should read. Mickey Catalan is a senior in high school. She‚Äôs a star softball player. She‚Äôs a friend. She‚Äôs a daughter. She‚Äôs an addict. Following a possible career ending car wreck with her best friend, Mickey is laid up in the hospital with screws holding her leg to her hip and a looming calendar reminding her of the approaching softball season. Mickey has to get better. Mickey has to be ready for conditioning. Mickey is prescribed OxyContin for pain and that‚Äôs where this story begins. I have never been so invested in a character than I was with this novel. I found myself screaming at her, angry with her, refusing to read another page- fantastic authors can torture you that way. The way Mickey slowly slides into the harrowing world of drugs is both mind blowing and terrifying. She justifies her actions in a way we have heard before, if you have ever known or loved an addict. She‚Äôs real. She‚Äôs heartbreaking. She‚Äôs a must read. To say I loved this book is a gross understatement. I would have given more than 5 stars ‚≠êÔ∏è if Goodreads would allow it. I downloaded the audio so I could listen in the car on the way to work, read on my lunch break, and late into the night; not caring how much sleep I got.  Favorite quote: ‚ÄúSometimes it‚Äôs hard to decide what‚Äôs the worst thing I ever did‚Äù  Run, don‚Äôt walk, to the nearest bookstore and devour this book. You will not be disappointed. Such an amazing read. @mindymcginnisauthor depiction of addiction is on point. This book is absolutely heartbreaking and reveals the cold, hard truth that many people don‚Äôt understand: opioid addiction can happen to ANYONE. #heroine #heroinebook #reading #bookstagram

i finished this book yesterday, but I had to sit and digest it for a little bit before I could write this review. I still don't know if I can do it justice. I simply might not have the words...so I think I'm going to start with one-word descriptions and go from there. "Powerful" is the first word that comes to mind. "Masterful" might be another. This book takes something that should be so one-sided (addiction) and turns it around so that you can see how easy it is to fall into it - and how it takes a heroine to get back out.
*
The book starts with the most chilling opening sentence I think I've ever read: "When I wake up, all my friends are dead." You have no idea who is speaking or why that person is alive when their friends are not. But with an opening line like that, how can you not read on? *
Mickey Catalan is a high school athlete. She plays softball; she's the catcher and her best friend Carolina is the pitcher. They've played together for years; they have their own codes and signals and can almost read each others minds. Then one day they're in Mickey's car, driving somewhere with pizza boxes on their lap, when they're hit by another car. Mickey gets thrown from the car; Carolina was not. Carolina ends up with a broken wrist, bad enough for a pitcher, but Mickey's hip is shattered. They're rescued by paramedics, and that's where the nightmare starts.
*
Little by little Mickey starts sliding down the slippery slope into addiction. She starts off right, taking her medicine as prescribed. Then it morphs from one pill to one and a half. Then to two. And before you know it her script has run out early. She goes for a follow-up appointment, asks for another script, and gets rejected. That would have been the end of it - until Edith stops her, gives her a pill to head off the withdrawal she's in, and puts her number in Mickey's phone. All of a sudden, the good-girl athlete has a dealer.
*
Continued in comments
